Uses of Class
be.kuleuven.micas.signals.Signal

Packages that use Signal
be.kuleuven.micas.signals Signal.java provides several useful end-user methods. 
be.kuleuven.micas.signalStorage Software package that allows to read signals from different types of simulation output. 
be.kuleuven.micas.signalStorage.interfaces interfaces for the simulation databases ( read this ) 
 

Uses of Signal in be.kuleuven.micas.signals
 

Methods in be.kuleuven.micas.signals that return Signal
 Signal Signal.add(double constant)
          create a new Signal which has the same attributes as this signal, but with yValues increased with the given constant
 Signal Signal.add(Signal s)
          return a signal which is the sum of this and s.
 Signal Signal.add(Signal s, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is the sum of this and s if samebase=true, no resampling of the values is done.
static Signal Signal.add(Signal s1, Signal s2)
          return a signal which is the sum of s1 and s2.
static Signal Signal.add(Signal s1, Signal s2, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is the sum of s1 and s2.
 Signal Signal.createConstantSignal(double constant)
          create a signal with the same xValues as this signal, but all yValues equal to constant
 Signal Signal.createRampSignal(double slope, double offset)
          Create a signal with the same xValues as this signal, but yValue = xValue*slope+offset That is, a line through ( 0, offset ) with the given slope
 Signal Signal.digitize(double lowThreshold, double highThreshold, double resultInbetween)
          returns a new Signal with the same xValues as this signal, but digitized if y[i]highThreshold, yr[i]=1 if lowThreshold
 Signal Signal.divide(double constant)
          create a new Signal which has the same attributes as this signal, but with yValues divided with the given constant
static Signal Signal.divide(Signal s1, Signal s2)
          return a signal which is the s1/s2.
static Signal Signal.divide(Signal s1, Signal s2, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is s1/s2.
 Signal Signal.divideBy(Signal s)
          return a signal which is the this/s.
 Signal Signal.divideBy(Signal s, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is this/s.

 Signal Signal.getInvertedSignal()

          create a subsignal from this signal, over the x-interval [ T1 ..
 Signal Signal.multiply(double constant)
          create a new Signal which has the same attributes as this signal, but with yValues multiplied with the given constant
 Signal Signal.multiply(Signal s)
          return a signal which is s1*s2.
 Signal Signal.multiply(Signal s, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is this*s if samebase=true, no resampling of the values is done.
static Signal Signal.multiply(Signal s1, Signal s2)
          return a signal which is the s1*s2.
static Signal Signal.multiply(Signal s1, Signal s2, boolean sameBase)

 Signal Signal.replaceValuesStrictlyAbove(double threshold, double replacement)
          create a copy of this signal in which all values strictly above threshold are replaced with replacement
 Signal Signal.replaceValuesStrictlyBelow(double threshold, double replacement)
          create a copy of this signal in which all values strictly below threshold are replaced with replacement
 Signal Signal.resample(double[] xValues)
          resample this signal at different xValues.
 Signal Signal.resampleGeneral(double[] xValues)
          resample this signal at different xValues.
 Signal Signal.reverse()
          return a new Signal in which the order of the xValues is reversed.
 Signal Signal.shiftToOriginX()
          create a new Signal where the xValues are shifted so that x[0]=0 result = this.shiftX( -x[0] )
 Signal Signal.shiftX(double deltaX)
          create a new Signal with xnew[i] = xold[i]+deltaX positive deltaX hence means a shift to the right
 Signal Signal.stretchX(double factor)
          create a new Signal with xnew[i] = xold[i]*factor
 Signal Signal.subtract(double constant)
          create a new Signal which has the same attributes as this signal, but with yValues decreased with the given constant
 Signal Signal.subtract(Signal s)
          return a signal which is the this-s.
 Signal Signal.subtract(Signal s, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is this-s.
static Signal Signal.subtract(Signal s1, Signal s2)
          return a signal which is the s1-s2.
static Signal Signal.subtract(Signal s1, Signal s2, boolean sameBase)
          return a signal which is s1-s2.
 Signal Signal.swapXY()
          create a new signal with swapped x and y values compared to this signal the new Signal's x-values are this signal's y-values the new Signal's y-values are this signal's x-values
